#Text=Estimating the benefits of floodplain restoration to juvenile Chinook salmon in the upper San Francisco Estuary, United States, under future climate scenarios.

#Text=Brock M Huntsman,�Marissa L Wulff,�Noah Knowles,�Ted Sommer,�Frederick V Feyrer,�Larry R Brown\rFirst published: 21 July 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14238\rAuthor contributions: BMH, MLW, LRB conceived and designed the research; BMH, MLW developed models and analyzed data; BMH, MLW, NK, TS, FVF, LRB wrote the manuscript; BMH, MLW, NK, TS, FVF edited the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: John Isanhart\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.

#Text=Many river systems within the Central Valley of California have been disconnected from their floodplains, hypothesized to be partially responsible for declining Chinook salmon populations (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha).

#Text=The primary floodplain of the system, Yolo By-Pass (known regionally as  Yolo Bypass ), offered an opportunity to examine whether improved connectivity between the floodplain and river could limit negative climate change effects on salmon populations.
#Text=Specifically, the top of the floodplain (Fremont Weir) is being modified to provide Sacramento River Chinook salmon better access to floodplain rearing habitat.
#Text=We estimated restoration effects on the Yolo By-Pass flood regime now and under future climate scenarios using flow rating curves.

#Text=Additionally, we used temperature and flow-specific effects on Chinook salmon population dynamics within the Yolo By-Pass and Sacramento River complex to describe how the restoration project and climate change may interact to affect juvenile Chinook salmon biomass production.
#Text=Our results indicate that the Fremont Weir restoration project will extend the frequency, timing, and duration of Yolo By-Pass flooding.

#Text=Our production model indicates that the modification will result in greater salmon entrainment rates into the Yolo By-Pass, where salmon growth rates, survival rates, and biomass production were higher when compared to the Sacramento River main stem.
#Text=The project appears to benefit all regional runs of Chinook salmon, which should help support life history diversity.

#Text=Our results suggest that the weir modification should benefit native fish from the Central Valley that use floodplain habitat and that these benefits may be resilient to challenges created by a changing climate.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Relatively simple restoration actions (e.g. putting a notch in a weir) can have a sizeable impact on recreating the natural habitat conditions from which native species have evolved.\r* Restoration actions that account for climate variability and climate change have the highest potential for success.\r* Coupled climate and ecological models can provide a useful evaluation of the complex interactions of climate change and habitat restoration.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Many restoration designs adopt flow regime concepts because flow regimes play an integral role in the structure and functioning of lotic ecosystems (Poff et al�1997; Naiman et al�2008).
#Text=The flow regime can shape community structure in aquatic environments by selecting taxa with life-history traits suitable for local persistence (Lytle & Poff�2004; Mims & Olden�2012).

#Text=For example, unnaturally stable flows and lower peak flows due to flood control and irrigation purposes can favor non-native fish assemblages with distinct life-history strategies (e.g. equilibrium) that were less prevalent under more natural conditions (Gido & Propst�2012; Mims & Olden�2013).

#Text=By mimicking a natural flow regime, aquatic and riparian community structure often returns to a more natural state (more native than non-native) because native species have evolved to these conditions (Propst et al�2008; Kiernan et al�2012).

#Text=However, mimicking a natural flow regime often requires creative solutions to provide both ecological benefits and maintain the function of flow management infrastructure (e.g. protect urban areas from flooding).
#Text=The effects of an altered flow regime are especially prevalent as they pertain to lateral floodplain connectivity, referred to as the flood regime from this point forward.
#Text=The floodplain serves an important role as spawning, rearing, and refugia habitat for many fish that have evolved life-history strategies within lotic ecosystems (Heim et al�2019).

#Text=For example, multiple salmon life stages in rivers may select off-channel habitat for reproduction and foraging because they often support complex hydraulics, temperature regimes, and geomorphic conditions favorable for offspring development (Huntsman & Falke�2019; Clawson et al�2022).

#Text=The presence of flow management infrastructure commonly affects lateral aspects of the natural flood regime by disconnecting floodplains from main stem flows (levees) and reducing the magnitude of flows that can inundate floodplains (dams) (Zhu et al�2007; Arrigoni et al�2010).

#Text=Issues created by lost connectivity with a river's floodplain can be addressed in several ways, including by creating managed floodways and moving levee systems away from river main channels for a greater area of floodplain connectivity (Matella & Merenlender�2015).

#Text=Reconnecting river main stems with their floodplains may play an important role in restoring an ecosystem's ability to support and sustain community structure and productivity (Naiman et al�2008; Bellmore et al�2013).
#Text=Climate change imposes additional stress on modified aquatic ecosystems and may complicate the efficacy of restoration actions that aim to reconnect rivers with their floodplains.
#Text=Climate change is expected to affect many aspects of the hydrograph and influence floodplain habitat access for lotic communities.

#Text=Projected warming of western U.S. streams may alter the timing of floodplain access within snowmelt-dominated riverscapes, while reduced precipitation could similarly affect the duration in which floodplain habitat is accessible to lotic communities (Tonina et al�2022).

#Text=Within California, United States, climate scenarios project warming temperatures and variable future precipitation, with river hydrographs expected to demonstrate peak flows earlier in the year due to a greater proportion of precipitation falling as rain instead of snow and snowmelt occurring earlier (Cloern et al�2011; Knowles et al�2018).
#Text=Consequently, the duration and frequency of lateral connectivity between many Californian rivers and their floodplains are expected to be impacted by a changing climate (Cloern et al�2011).
#Text=Chinook salmon is an iconic species along the Pacific Coast of North America.

#Text=Life-history diversity of Chinook salmon from the Central Valley of California is hypothesized to have evolved in response to the stochastic conditions that characterize the Mediterranean climate of the Central Valley (Sturrock et al�2020).

#Text=However, changing climate, impassable dams, flood protection infrastructure, and agriculture have altered the natural flow regime of most Central Valley rivers and are hypothesized to be partially responsible for lost trait diversity in Chinook salmon (Satterthwaite & Carlson�2015; Sturrock et al�2020).

#Text=The Central Valley is home to four runs of Chinook salmon, defined mostly by the timing of adult upstream migration and partially by geographic range and habitat use (Fisher�1994; Yoshiyama et al�2000).
#Text=Productive floodplain habitat is used by the different Chinook salmon runs as nursery habitat (Sommer et al�2001a; Jeffres et al�2020).

#Text=Although much of the existing flow management infrastructure in the Central Valley has reduced the connectivity between river systems and their floodplains, several key features provide salmon access to floodplain resources (Brown & Bauer�2010).
#Text=For example, floodways were constructed on historical floodplain habitat to divert flood waters away from urban settings.

#Text=These managed systems are used for several other purposes, including wildlife habitat and agriculture, and provide productive floodplain rearing conditions for Central Valley Chinook salmon (Sommer et al�2001b,�2005; Katz et al�2017).
#Text=The Yolo By-Pass floodplain is a floodway of the Sacramento River that was engineered to divert floodwaters away from urban infrastructure within the Central Valley (Fig�1).
#Text=As the primary floodplain of the San Francisco Estuary, the Yolo By-Pass provides seasonal habitat for fish spawning and rearing when inundated during the winter and spring months.

#Text=In recognition of the importance of the Yolo By-Pass to the ecology of the upper San Francisco Estuary, a suite of restoration actions is being implemented to improve its value to the system (Bureau of Reclamation & DWR�2019).

#Text=For young Chinook salmon, the most important of these projects is the construction of a notch in the low-head dam at the top of the Yolo By-Pass (Fremont Weir; Fig�1) to improve connectivity with the Sacramento River and increase the frequency and duration of seasonal inundation.
#Text=Currently, water enters the Yolo By-Pass by overtopping the Fremont Weir, which is the primary location for the Sacramento River to spill into the Yolo By-Pass.

#Text=The project is considered one of the most important actions to support the resilience of Chinook salmon in the Central Valley (NMFS�2019) by (1) addressing concerns about the possible effects of climate change on Chinook salmon viability (Herbold et al�2018; NMFS�2019) and (2) improving floodplain connectivity to support greater juvenile growth, survival, and life history diversity.
#Text=The goal of this study was to examine the potential interactions between climate change and improved connectivity between the Sacramento River and the Yolo By-Pass on Chinook salmon.

#Text=Given the complexity of this issue, we reasoned that a series of connected models would be needed to describe the interacting effects of habitat restoration and climate change on flow, temperature, and salmon biomass.
#Text=Our first objective was to describe the flood regime of the Yolo By-Pass under current and projected future climates with and without the notch modification to the Fremont Weir.

#Text=Second, we developed a model to quantify the effects of current and future climate scenarios with and without the notch modification on Chinook salmon biomass production using known temperature- and flow-related effects on Chinook salmon demography (e.g. apparent survival and movement) and growth within this region of the upper San Francisco Estuary.

#Text=Figure 1\rLocation of the Yolo By-Pass and Sacramento River (black polyline) salmon outmigration routes from the Fremont Weir to the Rio Vista Bridge within the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=The Yolo By-Pass includes a tidal, perennial channel (Toe Drain) along most of its eastern edge.
#Text=The blue shading south of the Yolo By-Pass is a flooded agricultural track of land.

#Text=Numbers are routes through the Sacramento River in which a salmon could travel as defined by Hance et al (2022): 1 = Fremont Weir-Feather River Confluence, 2 = Feather River Confluence-Sacramento, 3 = Sacramento-Freeport, 4 = Freeport-Steamboat Slough, 5 = Steamboat Slough-Georgiana Slough, and 6 = Georgiana Slough-Rio Vista Bridge.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Area.
#Text=The Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta is the upper freshwater extent of the San Francisco Estuary.

#Text=Two centuries of river alterations within the Central Valley for flood management and agricultural purposes have channeled river systems with levees and disconnected their natural floodplains (Florsheim & Dettinger�2015), resulting in a highly fragmented ecosystem that is prone to flooding cities and towns along the main stem river.

#Text=Consequently, the Yolo By-Pass was engineered as a flood management structure for the Sacramento River to divert floodwaters from the urban landscape and dissipate damaging flows from channelized stream corridors.
#Text=The Yolo By-Pass extends over 24,000 ha and is Sacramento River's primary floodplain, protecting Sacramento and surrounding urban areas from high flood flows.
#Text=The Sacramento River watershed experiences a Mediterranean climate, which is characterized by wet winters and dry summers (Florsheim & Dettinger�2015; Dettinger et al�2016).

#Text=The hydrology of the system is characterized by winter precipitation run-off, spring snowmelt from the Sierra Nevada to the east and the Cascade Range to the north, with flows sometimes supplemented by less predictable precipitation events throughout the year (Florsheim & Dettinger�2015).

#Text=The current flood regime of the Yolo By-Pass differs from unimpaired conditions because flow management infrastructure prevents the Yolo By-Pass from connecting to the Sacramento River in all but high flow events (Florsheim & Dettinger�2015).
#Text=During periods of high Sacramento River flow (greater than approximately 1585 m3/s), water from the river enters the northernmost point of the Yolo By-Pass by spilling over the Fremont Weir.

#Text=Currently, the Yolo By-Pass is inundated when the Sacramento River stage exceeds 10.2 m by a large amount and/or for a sustained period, causing it to overtop the Fremont Weir, the primary weir controlling inflow from the Sacramento River into the Yolo By-Pass.

#Text=During non-inundation periods, a perennial channel (Toe Drain) along the east side of the Yolo By-Pass conveys flow from local tributaries, as well as tidal flows from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.

#Text=An ongoing large-scale floodplain restoration project (anticipated completion, 2023�2024) that includes adding a gated notch to the Fremont Weir is intended to allow inundation of the Yolo By-Pass at lower Sacramento River flows during an operational window between November and March.

#Text=The notch is intended to increase the frequency and duration of flooding in the Yolo By-Pass, to improve fish passage and connectivity between the floodplain and the Sacramento River, increase floodplain rearing and spawning habitat, maintain flood control, and serve agricultural purposes (Bureau of Reclamation & DWR�2019).
#Text=Climate Projections.
#Text=Data for this project were generated from the U.S.

#Text=Geological Survey's Computational Assessments of Scenarios of Change for the Delta Ecosystem (CASCaDE2) project, which used 20 Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 climate scenarios, consisting of output from 10 global climate models (GCMs) each run with two representative concentration pathways (RCPs) (scenarios for future greenhouse gas concentrations) (Knowles et al�2018).

#Text=These two RCP pathways corresponded to radiative forcing values of 4.5 and 8.5 W/m2�by 2100, which represent a scenario with abated greenhouse gas emissions (RCP 4.5) and a high-end emissions scenario (RCP 8.5).

#Text=GCM-derived daily air temperature and precipitation for each of the 20 climate scenarios were generated for 1980�2099 on a 1/16 degree grid (Pierce et al�2014), and these projections were used by Knowles et al (2018) to project flows for the Sacramento watershed using models of watershed hydrology and operations.

#Text=For this study, we selected five downscaled GCMs with 4.5 and 8.5 W/m2�RCPs from the CASCaDE2 project that represented a wide range of temperature and precipitation scenarios for the Sacramento and San Joaquin River watersheds.

#Text=We selected a historical baseline (livneh) for water years 1980�2009 (Livneh et al�2015; Knowles et al�2018) and future projections from 2010 to 2099 that included warm-dry (model name = MIROC5), warm-wet (CNRM-CM5), hot-dry (HadGEM2-CC), and hot-wet (CanESM2) scenarios (Table�1).
#Text=Further details on these projections can be found in Knowles et al (2018).
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�Global climate models (GCM) used for air and water temperature predictions within the San Francisco Estuary, California.

#Text=GCM\rModeling Center\rCanESM2\rCanadian Centre for Climate Modeling and Analysis\rCNRM-CM5\rCentre National de Recherches Meteorologiques/Centre Europeen de Recherche et Formation Avancee en Calcul Scientifique, France\rHadGEM2-CC\rMet Office Hadley Centre, United Kingdom\rMIROC5\rAtmosphere and Ocean Research Institute, National Institute for Environmental Studies, and Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology\rThe Yolo By-Pass flow data used in this analysis were from the CASCaDE2 project's projections of the combined flow in the Yolo By-Pass and Sacramento River at Verona (Knowles et al�2018; U.S.
#Text=Geological Survey�2023).

#Text=Additional details about the hydrodynamics models developed to project flows in response to notch planning and to split projected flows between the Yolo By-Pass and Sacramento River for this study can be found in Supplement�S1�(Figures�S1�and�S2).
#Text=Projected water temperatures in the Yolo By-Pass near Woodland and in the Sacramento River near Hood (Fig�1) were taken from Wulff et al�(2021a).
#Text=All temperature and flow data are published in Wulff et al�(2021a,�2021b).
#Text=Objective 1: Yolo By-Pass Flood Regime\rWe summarized the time series of daily Yolo By-Pass flow projections into annual flood regime metrics (Poff et al�1997; Mims & Olden�2012).

#Text=These metrics describe five components of a hydrograph within a water year (October 1�September 30), reflecting the magnitude, duration, frequency, and timing of flood events and the variability in the number of flood events within a water year.
#Text=All flood regime metrics were calculated for projected flows within the Yolo By-Pass during flood events when flows were projected to occur on the floodplain.
#Text=These flood events were defined by two scenarios: (1) any projected flow onto the Yolo By-Pass (projected m3/s >0) and (2) any meaningful flow onto the Yolo By-Pass (projected m3/s >113).

#Text=We defined a meaningful flood event on the Yolo By-Pass as flows greater than 113 m3/s because this threshold was considered appropriate to support life-history events of native fish in the region (e.g. spawning for Sacramento Splittail,�Pogonichthys macrolepidotus; Sommer et al�2001a; Cloern et al�2011).
#Text=Note that a meaningful flood event as defined by Cloern et al (2011) also requires the 113 m3/s flood event to occur for 30 days, which we capture in our analyses as metric f2 (see below).

#Text=We calculated two magnitude metrics (m1, m2), two timing metrics (t1, t2), two frequency metrics (f1, f2), two duration metrics (d1, d2), and one variability metric (v1, see Table�2�for definitions) by water year for each flood event.

#Text=We used a principal component analysis (PCA) to describe variation in flood regime metrics (Mims & Olden�2013) calculated for the Yolo By-Pass based on climate projections, Fremont Weir notch implementation, and flood event definition (Yolo By-Pass m3/s >0 vs. m3/s >113).

#Text=We used the  MASS  package (Venables & Ripley�2002) from the R software program (R Core Team�2021) and a correlation matrix to standardize all flood regime metrics (to mean = 0 and standard deviation = 1) when fitting the PCA.
#Text=We identified factor loadings by correlating the original flood regime metrics with each principal component (PC) score.
#Text=Table 2.

#Text=�Factor loadings of each natural flow regime metric on each principal component (PC) axes fit to projected flows of the Yolo By-Pass floodplain within the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=Note that projected flows into the Yolo By-Pass are capped at 850 m3/s (see Supplement�S1).

#Text=Regime\rMetric\rDefinition\rPC1\rPC2\rDuration\rd1\rTotal number of days flooded\r0.96\r0.10\r\rd2\rDuration of the largest flood\r0.89\r 0.10\rFrequency\rf1\rTotal number of flood events\r0.78\r0.13\r\rf2\rTotal number of flood events lasting longer than 29 days\r0.90\r0.07\rMagnitude\rm1\rMean discharge of all flood events\r 0.17\r 0.93\r\rm2\rCumulative discharge of all flood events\r0.56\r 0.59\rTiming\rt1\rDay of first flood event\r 0.18\r 0.73\r\rt2\rDay of last flood event\r0.86\r0.15\rVariability\rv1\rRange of max flows for all flood events\r0.73\r0.00\r\r\rStandard deviation\r2.19\r1.34\r\r\rProportion of variance explained\r0.53\r0.20\rObjective 2: Chinook Salmon Production Model\rWe built an out-migrating production model based on Chinook-salmon-specific flow and temperature-related demographic rates.

#Text=The model is based on secondary production principles (Equation�1, biomass production from this point forward), with the response as the accumulation of heterotrophic biomass over an annual time scale (P; Wipfli & Baxter�2010)
#Text=.
#Text=(1)\rwhere��is an abundance sub-model,��is a Yolo By-Pass entrainment sub-model,� �is an apparent survival sub-model, and��is a bioenergetics sub-model.

#Text=Abundance Sub-Model ( )\rWe used the Knights Landing rotary screw trap data collected by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (Fig�1) to estimate the starting population size of each salmon run�r�for the model.
#Text=Salmon run was determined using length-at-date criteria for the Sacramento River (Greene�1992).

#Text=We took the maximum number of Chinook salmon run�r�captured on day�t�between 2014 and 2022 during the Knights Landing screw trap operation (e.g. the maximum number of salmon captured on day 1 between 2014 and 2022) and estimated total abundance by adjusting for screw trap sampling efficiency of 0.52% (Julienne et al�2020) by the following:\r(2)\rwhere��is the maximum number of salmon run�r�captured in the Knights Landing screw trap on the day of the water year�t�between 2014 and 2022.
#Text=Route Selection Sub-Model ( )\rWe developed a Chinook salmon route selection sub-model based on flow effects on entrainment probability into the Yolo By-Pass.
#Text=Chinook salmon acoustic telemetry studies have shown that entrainment into the Yolo By-Pass increases with flow (Pope et al�2021; Hance et al�2022).

#Text=We defined Yolo By-Pass routing probability () with the following equation:\r(3)\rwhere��is projected Yolo By-Pass discharge on day�t�of year�x, for climate scenario�c, and management scenario�m�(notch or no notch in the Fremont Weir).

#Text=Pope et al (2021) estimated salmon entrainment probability into the Yolo By-Pass to be 4% (lower-upper 90% credible interval = 0.8�11.3%) during the receding limb of a flood event and 80% (lower-upper 90% credible interval = 68.7�89.0%; Table�S1) during the peak of the flood event (Pope et al�2021).

#Text=Variability in��was incorporated into the analysis for each of the 100 simulations (i) by randomly selecting from a normal distribution around the mean and standard deviation of the��parameter estimate (Pope et al�2021).

#Text=We generated the total number of salmon moving into the Yolo By-Pass () as a random draw from a binomial distribution (), and the total number that stayed within the Sacramento River () as the difference between the starting population size and the number routed into the Yolo By-Pass (=).

#Text=Survival Sub-Model ( )\rWe used flow and temperature information to predict the apparent survival rates of salmon moving through the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta based on models developed by Hance et al (2022).

#Text=Hance et al (2022) estimated apparent survival rates of salmon in the Sacramento River to be positively affected by flows and negatively affected by water temperatures along six distinct sections of the Sacramento River between the Fremont Weir and the Rio Vista Bridge (1 = Fremont Weir-Feather River Confluence, 2 = Feather River Confluence-Sacramento, 3 = Sacramento-Freeport, 4 = Freeport-Steamboat Slough, 5 = Steamboat Slough-Georgiana Slough, and 6 = Georgiana Slough-Rio Vista Bridge; Fig�1).

#Text=The Hance et al (2022) model used historical flows measured at Freeport, but flow projections are not available for Freeport, so we instead used projected temperature data from the Hood location because it was the closest site to Freeport (Fig�1; Wulff et al�2021a).
#Text=We also did not have projected flow information for the Freeport station used by Hance et al (2022) and instead used projected flows at the Sacramento River at Verona gage (U.S.

#Text=Geological Survey�2023) that were converted to flows at Freeport using regression analysis (Freeport m3/s =  3.56 + 1.17   Verona m3/s) because observed data indicated Freeport and Verona stations have similar flows (Fig�S3).
#Text=Hance et al (2022) did not find a strong temperature or flow effect on the apparent survival of salmon within the Yolo By-Pass.

#Text=Therefore, we did not include covariate effects on salmon survival within the Yolo By-Pass and used apparent survival estimates at two distinct sections within the Yolo By-Pass modeled by Hance et al (2022) (Fremont Weir-Toe Drain and Toe Drain-Rio Vista Bridge; Fig�1).

#Text=We estimated the total number of salmon that survived traveling within each route (,�) with the following equations:\r    (4)\rwhere�,�, and��are section-specific regression coefficients from Hance et al (2022), describing the intercept, temperature effect, and flow effects on salmon apparent survival ( ), respectively.

#Text=Similar to the route selection sub-model, uncertainty in regression coefficient estimates was incorporated into��estimates for each of the 100 simulations by randomly selecting from a normal distribution around the mean and standard deviation of the parameter estimates found in Hance et al (2022).

#Text=Bioenergetics Sub-Model (  )\rSalmon that access the Yolo By-Pass demonstrate improved somatic growth compared to salmon occupying the Sacramento River (Sommer et al�2001a,�2005; Jeffres et al�2020).

#Text=To account for somatic growth differences in our production model, we used a juvenile Chinook salmon fish bioenergetics model (Stewart & Ibarra�1991; Plumb & Moffitt�2015) to estimate biomass gained by salmon using the Yolo By-Pass or Sacramento River.

#Text=Fish bioenergetics is a mass-balance equation in the form of:\r(5)\rwhere fish growth rates () are equivalent to food consumption rates () minus losses due to egestion rates (), excretion rates (), respiration rates (), and specific dynamic action (), all of which are described as mass and temperature dependent rates (Table�S1).

#Text=We re-arranged the bioenergetics mass-balance equation to predict consumption rates (proportion of maximum consumption,�) based on published instantaneous growth rates of Chinook salmon reared in either the Yolo By-Pass (mean = 0.93 +/- 0.15 SD mm/day) or the Sacramento River (mean = 0.18 +/- 0.09 SD mm/day; Jeffres et al�2020).

#Text=Although salmon consume multiple prey items between these habitats (Goertler et al�2018a), we used aquatic macroinvertebrates as the one prey category for bioenergetic simulations because our goal was to simulate growth differences among habitats, not how prey quality affects growth.
#Text=Jeffres et al (2020) performed growth experiments around March of 2016, with Chinook salmon starting sizes of 55 mm fork length.

#Text=We estimated the size of the same fish after 5 days rearing in each habitat and converted starting and ending sizes within each habitat to mass using length-mass regressions (Table�S1; Kimmerer et al�2005).

#Text=We randomly selected from a normal distribution the mean and standard deviation of growth rates for salmon in each habitat with 100 simulations and used fish bioenergetics to predict a distribution for��in each habitat.

#Text=We used projected water temperatures from Hood and Woodland in March of 2016 to predict��for salmon growth reported in Jeffres et al (2020) from the Sacramento River and Yolo By-Pass, respectively.
#Text=We used the mean and standard deviation for��within each habitat for growth simulations under different management (with vs. without the notch) and climate scenarios.

#Text=Hance et al (2022) found that salmon travel time through the Sacramento River was affected by flow at the Freeport gaging station, while travel time through the Yolo By-Pass was less dependent on flow, although there was some evidence for a negative flow effect on travel time between the Toe Drain and the Rio Vista Bridge based on 90% credible intervals.

#Text=We estimated the number of days to travel through either the Yolo By-Pass or Sacramento River between the Fremont Weir and Rio Vista Bridge () with the following equations:\r(6)\rwhere��and��are regression coefficients representing an intercept and flow effect on travel time, respectively.
#Text=Travel time estimates were made and summed for each of the six sections of the Sacramento River and two sections of the Yolo By-Pass, as previously described for apparent survival above.
#Text=We estimated growth rates (  , g of mass accumulated) for each salmon run using fish bioenergetics (see Equation�5).
#Text=Salmon starting size was specific to a salmon run and day of year based on length-run relationships (Table�S1; Fisher�1992; Harvey�2011; Harvey et al�2014).

#Text=The predicted length of a salmon based on run and day of the water year (Fig�2) was then converted to mass using the salmon length-�weight relationship (Kimmerer et al�2005) to start each model run.
#Text=Length-run relationships were mostly based on the peak emergence timing of each run.
#Text=For example, peak emergence for a fall run salmon occurs on February 1 (Fisher�1992; Harvey�2011) and predicted length is determined based on the number of days after February 1.
#Text=However, no salmon captured in the screw trap exceeded 200 mm fork length.
#Text=Therefore, if predicted length-run relationships resulted in a predicted length greater than 200 mm fork length, we used the late emergence date for that specific run (e.g.
#Text=April 1 for fall run salmon) to predict a starting salmon size for the model (reason for broken lines in Fig�2).

#Text=Growth rates were simulated for each route, day, climate scenario, and management scenario using route-specific estimates of daily�, water temperatures, and the predicted length of time required for a fish to move through the route (), with the growth estimate reflecting the amount of mass gained over the simulation period (i.e.�   = final mass � starting mass).

#Text=Figure 2\rScaled salmon run size (0�100%) based on maximum counts detected at Knights Landing from screw trap records and predicted fork length (mm) of each salmon run on an individual day of the year entering the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=Vertical gray bands represent seasonal breaks over the water year (1 October to 30 September).

#Text=Final production estimates were made by water year, salmon run, climate scenario, management scenario, and route using the following equation:\r(7)\rwhere total production by route (; Yolo By-Pass or Sacramento River) was summed by each of the 300 days in which the simulation was run.

#Text=We removed the last 65 days of each water year from the simulation because few salmon were detected from the Knights Landing screw trap between days 300 and 365 of the simulation (corresponds to days 208�273 or July 27�September 30; Fig�2).

#Text=This restricted window for our production calculation made all estimates comparable by water year in case a scenario resulted in salmon travel times spanning two water years (e.g. captured at the Knights Landing screw trap on September 28 and required 3 or more days to reach Rio Vista).

#Text=Lastly, we performed a one-factor-at-a-time sensitivity analysis (Ten Broeke et al�2016) to assess the sensitivity of our salmon production model to variability in each model parameter (see Supplement�S2).
#Text=Results.
#Text=Objective 1: Yolo by-Pass Flood Regime\rProjected flows into the Yolo By-Pass were consistent with our climate model classifications (e.g. hot-dry and hot-wet).

#Text=We found the cumulative amount of flow projected for an entire year on the Yolo By-Pass (see Table�2�for m2 definition) was greater on average for the warm-wet and hot-wet scenarios than the warm-dry and hot-dry scenarios (Fig�S4).

#Text=All  wet  climate scenarios resulted in greater projections of cumulative flows by the end of the century than the start of projections (2009), while dry climate scenarios resulted in less cumulative flow within a water year by the end of the century when compared to the start of projections (Fig�S4).
#Text=Most of the variability in the Yolo By-Pass flood regime was explained by the first two PC axes (73% of variability), with 53% explained by PC 1 and 20% by PC 2 (Table�2).
#Text=The projected flood regime parameters were affected by the notch in the Yolo By-Pass when compared with the no-notch scenarios (Fig�3).

#Text=However, separation of flood regimes based on notch and no-notch scenarios was most obvious when floods were defined as any flow on the Yolo By-Pass (>0 m3/s) as opposed to meaningful flows greater than 113 m3/s on the Yolo By-Pass (Fig�3).

#Text=The projected flood regime indicated greater duration and frequency metrics (d1, d2, f1, and f2 as summarized by PC 1) with the notch while no-notch scenarios projected greater mean magnitude metrics (PC 2; Table�2; Figs.�3�&�4).

#Text=Timing metrics indicated that the flood regime with the notch projected an earlier timing in which the first flood event would occur and later timing for the last flood event when compared to the no-notch scenario (Figs.�3�&�4).

#Text=Figure 3\r\rPrincipal component analysis of historical (baseline) and future (RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5) flow regime metrics for selected GCM's (baseline = livneh, warm-wet = CNRM-CM5, warm-dry = HadGEM2-CC, hot-wet = CanESM2, and hot-dry = MIROC5) calculated for the Yolo By-Pass with and without the Fremont Weir notch within the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=Flow regime metrics are defined in Table�1, with factor loadings in parentheses.

#Text=Flow regime metrics were calculated for any level of flow into the Yolo By-Pass defined as a flood (any flow, m3/s >0) and when flows were considered meaningful within the Yolo By-Pass (meaningful flow, m3/s >113).
#Text=Note that projected flows into the Yolo By-Pass are capped at 850 m3/s (see Supplement�S1).
#Text=Figure 4\r\rFlood regime metrics summarized by management scenario (notch vs. no notch) and climate scenario within the Yolo By-Pass of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=Scenarios also include defining a flood event as any projected flow into the Yolo By-Pass (any flow, m3/s >0) or as a meaningful flow into the Yolo By-Pass (meaningful flow, m3/s >113).
#Text=Future climate scenarios presented are only for the RCP 8.5 emission scenario.
#Text=Future climate models include a warm-wet (CNRM-CM5), warm-dry (HadGEM2-CC), hot-wet (CanESM2), and hot-dry (MIROC5) scenario for just the RCP 8.5 emission scenario.
#Text=Note that timing metrics t1 (day of first flood) and t2 (day of last flood) were set to days 365 and 0 when no  flood  event was observed.

#Text=Objective 2: Chinook Salmon Production Model\rThe range and frequency of parameter estimates (e.g. entrainment probability and apparent survival) used to estimate production for each Chinook salmon run for each simulation can be found in Figures�S5�S8.

#Text=Sensitivity analysis (see Supplement�S2) indicated that salmon production rates were most sensitive to variability in the growth sub-model for high entrainment rate scenarios ( = 0.80) and most sensitive to variability in entrainment rates for low entrainment rate scenarios ( = 0.04; Fig�S10).
#Text=From production simulations, mean production rates were estimated to be higher with the notch than without the notch for all salmon runs and climate scenarios (Fig�5).

#Text=Among runs, production rates were projected to be highest for fall and spring run Chinook salmon with (mean production >83 kg of accumulated biomass/year from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta) and without the notch (mean production >43 kg of accumulated biomass/year from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta), while lowest for late fall run (mean production <16 kg of accumulated biomass/year from the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta with and without the notch; Fig�5).

#Text=Figure 5\r\rTotal secondary production of Chinook salmon within the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California, based on projected flow scenarios under historical (baseline: 1980�2009) and future climate (2010�2099) for the RCP 8.5 emission scenario.
#Text=Future climate models include a warm-wet (CNRM-CM5), warm-dry (HadGEM2-CC), hot-wet (CanESM2), and hot-dry (MIROC5) scenario for just the RCP 8.5 emission scenario.

#Text=Chinook salmon projected production rates varied by route through the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta (Yolo By-Pass or Sacramento River main stem), management scenarios (notch vs. no notch), and climate scenarios.
#Text=Total Chinook salmon biomass production increased as greater amounts of flow were projected onto the Yolo By-Pass (Fig�6).

#Text=When broken down by route, projected rates of salmon biomass production decreased within the Sacramento River but increased within the Yolo By-Pass with increasing cumulative annual Yolo By-Pass flows for fall and late fall salmon runs (Fig�S9).
#Text=Regardless of the climate scenario, biomass production of all salmon runs was higher with the notch than without the notch (Fig�7).
#Text=The relative difference in production with the notch compared to without the notch was greatest for the dry climate scenarios when compared to the wet scenarios (Fig�7).

#Text=Figure 6\r\rEstimated secondary production of biomass for fall run Chinook salmon moving through the Yolo By-Pass and the Sacramento River as a function of cumulative flow within the Yolo By-Pass projected under future climate scenarios with and without the Fremont Weir notch, within the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=Production projections are means with 95% CIs (95% quantiles) represented by vertical bars.

#Text=Climate scenarios include the baseline condition (1980�2009: livneh), a warm-wet (2010�2099: CNRM-CM5), warm-dry (2010�2099: HadGEM2-CC), hot-wet (2010�2099: CanESM2), and hot-dry (2010�2099: MIROC5) scenario for just the RCP 8.5 emission scenario.
#Text=Note that projected flows into the Yolo By-Pass are capped at 850 m3/s (see Supplement�S1).

#Text=Figure 7\r\rTotal secondary production projected for each Chinook salmon run by management scenario (notch vs. no notch) within the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of the San Francisco Estuary, California.
#Text=Values are means across all iterations.
#Text=The broken line represents a 1:1 relationship.

#Text=Climate scenarios include the baseline condition (1980�2009: Livneh), a warm-wet (2010�2099: CNRM-CM5), warm-dry (2010�2099: HadGEM2-CC), hot-wet (2010�2099: CanESM2), and hot-dry (2010�2099: MIROC5) scenario for just the RCP 8.5 emission scenario.
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=The goal of our study was to examine the current and future benefits of a major flow restoration project, the notch of the Fremont Weir, by modeling flow and Chinook salmon production under the current baseline and various future temperature and precipitation conditions.

#Text=Proactive actions that anticipate and remedy issues before they manifest are valuable for mitigating human impacts on river ecosystems, such as issues created by a changing climate (Palmer et al�2008).

#Text=In water-stressed areas in highly developed watersheds, such as the Central Valley, wetland creation and reconnecting floodplains with river main stem habitats are strategies that could be beneficial to remedy issues created by a changing climate (Palmer et al�2008).

#Text=Here, we used a network of information on Chinook salmon population dynamics and a climate modeling effort to quantify potential ecological benefits that a restoration action (notch in the Fremont Weir) may have for a floodplain-main stem riverscape of the Central Valley.

#Text=Flood Regime of the Yolo By-Pass\rOur results demonstrated that the Fremont Weir notch will have the greatest effect on the flood regime of the Yolo By-Pass at low flows (flows less than 113 m3/s).

#Text=Climate projections from CASCaDE2 anticipate a warming climate, variable amounts of precipitation, but also more frequent and severe dry years for the future Central Valley (Knowles et al�2018).
#Text=Additionally, less snowpack is projected for Central Valley watersheds, potentially resulting in less flow during dry seasons.

#Text=Our results suggest that the Fremont Weir notch may help buffer some of the negative effects that a future climate could have by reducing the amount of flow from the Sacramento River needed to inundate the Yolo By-Pass.

#Text=We found that the Fremont Weir notch is projected to increase biomass production for all Central Valley Chinook salmon runs (discussed more fully below), and these benefits are likely to extend to other native fish within the Central Valley.
#Text=The Yolo By-Pass is inhabited by native fish with conservation interest (e.g.

#Text=White sturgeon�Acipenser transmontanus�and Splittail�Pogonichthys macrolepidotus), many of which benefit from somatic growth and reproduction (Sommer et al�2003; Miller et al�2020) when using the Yolo By-Pass (Feyrer et al�2006; Mahardja et al�2019).

#Text=For example, Splittail year-class strength is correlated to days of Yolo By-Pass inundation during spring spawning months (>3 weeks inundated; Sommer et al�2003; Feyrer et al�2006), and our results demonstrate that flow passing Fremont Weir longer than 29 days more than doubled with than without the notch.

#Text=Central Valley Chinook Salmon Production in Response to Climate and Management Scenarios\rOur results demonstrated that projected salmon biomass production was affected by entrainment probability in the Yolo By-Pass.

#Text=Our model showed greater production of all Chinook salmon runs with discharge in the Yolo By-Pass, while the opposite relationship was projected for salmon biomass production within the Sacramento River, reflecting the higher entrainment probability of salmon into the Yolo By-Pass with higher flows (Pope et al�2021; Hance et al�2022).
#Text=These effects on entrainment probability were most noticeable when comparing the management scenarios, with greater salmon entrainment probability and production associated with the notch.

#Text=Similar assumptions and model outcomes for salmon entrainment rates in response to the notch scenario have been described elsewhere, where entrainment rates of Chinook salmon were estimated to increase by as much as 280% after including the notch in the Fremont Weir (Acierto et al�2014).
#Text=Production of all Chinook salmon runs increased with cumulative flow on the Yolo By-Pass, which was directly affected by the management scenario (notch vs. no notch).
#Text=The benefits of these management scenarios on salmon production were most obvious when considering projections during low flow conditions.

#Text=For example, we found that differences in salmon production for all runs between notch and no-notch scenarios were projected to be greatest under the dry future climate scenarios (HadGEM2-CC and MIROC5).

#Text=The presence of the notch under dry climate scenarios resulted in a greater number of salmon accessing the Yolo By-Pass due to less flow needed to pass the Fremont Weir, unlike in wet scenarios where more frequent high flow events provided salmon access to a flooded Yolo By-Pass regardless of the notch.
#Text=The notch may also help address climate-related issues caused by earlier run-off and its implications for the productivity of different Chinook salmon runs.

#Text=For example, a higher number of late fall and spring run Chinook salmon were detected at the Knight's Landing screw trap later in the water year (March�April) than earlier (prior to March), a time of year when the Yolo By-Pass typically has less flow (without the notch).

#Text=Since the notch is projected to extend the duration of flooding into the Yolo By-Pass and extend the timing in which the last flood event may occur within a given year, the later-arriving salmon runs will have opportunities to access the Yolo By-Pass under drier conditions than they can without the notch.
#Text=Chinook salmon moving through the Sacramento River and Yolo By-Pass complex must navigate a network of natural and human-made channels, making for a relatively complex risk-reward landscape.

#Text=Flow affects the rate at which Chinook salmon move through this system, the probability that they are routed into different channels, and salmon survival (Perry et al�2018; Hance et al�2022), although the discharge effects on movement and survival are weaker in the Yolo By-Pass than elsewhere (Johnston et al�2018; Hance et al�2022).
#Text=This tempered discharge effect on travel time in the Yolo By-Pass may reflect the higher reward and lower risks for salmon using the Yolo By-Pass relative to other outmigration routes (e.g.
#Text=Sacramento River, Georgiana Slough, and Delta Cross Channel).

#Text=The greater production in the Yolo By-Pass than Sacramento River found in our study may partially reflect the extent to which risks relative to rewards (e.g. predator exposure vs. growth potential) shape salmon behavior on the Yolo By-Pass when inundated.

#Text=Our results suggest that extended access to the Yolo By-Pass due to the notch modification has the potential to supplement each of the four Central Valley Chinook salmon runs moving through the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta.
#Text=Our model showed a direct relationship between flow on the Yolo By-Pass and the presence of the notch on biomass production for all salmon runs.
#Text=Beyond juvenile production benefits, expanded access to the Yolo By-Pass may also extend to benefits in resiliency of the different salmon runs.

#Text=For example, Goertler et al�(2018b) showed that variability in juvenile Chinook salmon size structure (a proxy for life-history diversity) on the Yolo By-Pass was best explained by the duration of inundation.

#Text=Resilience of the Central Valley Chinook salmon population is linked to the portfolio of life-history strategies that juvenile and adult salmon possess within the system (Satterthwaite & Carlson�2015).

#Text=Consequently, our model suggests that the extended flood regime of the Yolo By-Pass due to the notch modification could create a more stable Central Valley Chinook salmon population through portfolio effects now and into the future.

#Text=Although our salmon production model made several assumptions to simplify the salmon Yolo By-Pass ecosystem, the model could easily be adjusted to incorporate more complexity into the study system.
#Text=First, our model simplified the study system to only include the Fremont Weir as the access point for salmon to be entrained into the Yolo By-Pass.
#Text=Although the Fremont Weir is the primary location for salmon entrainment from the Sacramento River, smaller tributaries west of the Yolo By-Pass (e.g.
#Text=Putah Creek and Cache Creek), upstream movement, and smaller access points along the levee system may all contribute to juvenile salmon access to the Yolo By-Pass (Johnston et al�2018).

#Text=Additionally, salmon that were not entrained within the Yolo By-Pass were assumed to follow one route along the Sacramento River to Rio Vista, which does not incorporate the complex network of channels in which salmon could also be entrained (e.g.
#Text=Georgiana Slough and Delta Cross Channel; Perry et al�2018).
#Text=Although many of these routes show a similar temperature and discharge effect on salmon demography (Perry et al�2018; Hance et al�2022), some routes may be riskier than others for salmon (e.g.
#Text=Georgiana Slough; Perry et al�2018).
#Text=Lastly, other salmon entrainment models have been developed for the Yolo By-Pass with and without the notch in place.

#Text=These models use various particle tracking methods and assumptions about salmon entrainment rates in response to the relative amount of Sacramento River flow anticipated to pass through the notch (Acierto et al�2014; Bureau of Reclamation & DWR�2019).

#Text=Although we decided to use empirical data to parameterize salmon entrainment rates on the Yolo By-Pass, other entrainment rate models could easily be incorporated into our model and may be found to better reflect true entrainment rates once the notch is operational.
#Text=Our model, like any model, contained assumptions that impacted how the notch modification to the Fremont Weir affected salmon production.
#Text=First, we used length-run classifications for salmon run assignments, which could be responsible for overestimating biomass production for some salmon runs and underestimation for others.
#Text=For example, many late fall run salmon are incorrectly assigned to fall run classifications based on length-run keys (Brandes et al�2021).
#Text=These misclassifications could be responsible for an overestimation of fall run and an underestimation of late fall run biomass production.
#Text=Furthermore, our model assumes that any use of the Yolo By-Pass will result in significantly higher growth rates than for fish in the Sacramento River.

#Text=However, salmon within the Yolo By-Pass were found to experience a smaller growth advantage than main stem Sacramento River salmon when constrained to only a perennial drainage canal on the Yolo By-Pass, unlike salmon on the Yolo By-Pass that access flooded agricultural wetlands (Jeffres et al�2020).
#Text=Therefore, our model may overestimate salmon production if notch operations do not result in greater access to floodplain productivity.
#Text=Our sensitivity analysis indicated that salmon production rates were most sensitive to growth rates, especially for high entrainment rate scenarios.

#Text=High Yolo By-Pass entrainment rate scenarios resulted in high growth rates for most of the salmon in our model, which may not be realistic if higher entrainment rates do not correspond to access to habitat beyond the perennial drainage canal.
#Text=Restoration actions offer a tool to buffer the long-term effects of climate change, but it is unclear whether the benefits will be sufficient to sustain populations.

#Text=Lateral connectivity with floodplain habitat is a natural feature of healthy river ecosystems, and we showed that the Fremont Weir notch modification may extend the duration, timing, and frequency by which the river will be actively connected with the Yolo By-Pass.
#Text=The degree to which this restoration action modified floodplain flows was greater than that projected from climate change.

#Text=Consequently, this management action has the potential to increase biomass production of all salmon runs and mitigate climate-change impacts that are anticipated for the Central Valley due to the reduced snowpack, allowing for prolonged activation of the Yolo By-Pass even with the reduced flows projected to occur later in the year.

#Text=Collectively, these conditions suggest that the notch modification may allow for the river ecosystem to reflect natural conditions more closely, benefiting the native fish that have evolved in this ecosystem.
